I'm glad I read this book while I'm at college, because I don't know that I could ever find it except at a university library. Thorwald makes a fictional character of his grandfather, who lived during this century of several surgical breakthroughs. Because of the narrative format, the book reads a little less like a history and moves a bit more quickly.The story takes place in the 19th century. Thorwald begins by talking about three different types of surgery done before the discovery of anesthesia. Developments covered in the book include anesthesia and painless surgery, sepsis and aseptic technique, and ends with the first successful heart surgery.I was amazed to see how hard many of the discoverers of new techniques had to work to get the greater surgical world to accept and use their better methods. Thorwald describes the whole history of medicine development between 1830's and 1930's. Thes is a breathtaking story of medical inventions having been related to the development of surgery. The author begins with almost criminal story of anaesthesia, and the tragic fate of its creators: Horace Wells, William Morton and Jackson- all sadly ended up fatally. The invention of aseptics and antiseptics are being described in-depth, the first surgical operation on the open heart, on the incurable stomach cancers and brain melanomas. Thornwald was a historiam of medicine, his grandfather was the eye-witness of the first surgical operation in Massachussets with the use of ether in 1836, when he was a medical student at the university.
